Award.AbstractNarration: For a general class of random matrices of size $n$ having independent entries, the typical eigenvalue is of order $\sqrt n$. We had investigated the large deviation properties when we are looking for eigenvalues that are of order $n$. We had looked at the case when the tails decay faster than Gaussian and now plan to examine the Gaussian case and we expect the results to be somewhat different.Large deviation theory deals with the estimation of probabilities of rare events. They are necessarily tiny and are often exponentially small in some natural parameter. The theory deals with estimating with some precision the exponential rate. When we study sums of random variables this often involves the estimation of the expectation of exponential moments of the sums. We have proposed to examine this phenomena in certain sums of unusual but general form that have applications to other contexts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Interacting partcle systems studies the collective behaviour of a large systems where each component interacts with only a few neighbors. There are usually conserved quantities in the interaction. While the individual components may change rapidly the conserved quantities, while conserved globally will change locally at a slow rate. The relatively rapid local changes will have an effect on the evolution of conserved quantities.   This produces some nonlinerar effcts on the collective behavior. The goal is to understand this relationship.  Large deviation theory plays an important role in it.

Large Deviation theory is about estimating precisely very small probabilities. Over the years we had investigated this theory and developed methods that treat  successfully some of the problems in interacting systems. The calculation of the small probability will of course depend on the model used, and we can change the model so that the probability of the event we  are intersted in is not so small, perhaps even close to 1. There may be several models that might accomplish this. Suppose changing the model has a cost, then we would  want to minimize it and the mininmal cost will tell us how samll the probability is. The "cost" that works is Relative Entropy or Kullback-Leibler information.

While most of  the studies have been on the behavior of a large collection of identical particles, the collective behaviour of systems with multiple types have not been investigated  thoroughly. It is a project worth developing and may lead to a better understanding of complex systems.
